skill.name: networkx
skill.description: Comprehensive toolkit for creating, analyzing, and visualizing complex networks and graphs in Python. Use when working with network/graph data structures, analyzing relationships between entities, computing graph algorithms (shortest paths, centrality, clustering), detecting communities, generating synthetic networks, or visualizing network topologies. Applicable to social networks, biological networks, transportation systems, citation networks, and any domain involving pairwise relationships.
skill.summary: Comprehensive toolkit for creating, analyzing, and visualizing complex networks and graphs in Python...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation with Python code examples for the NetworkX library. No executable scripts, network calls, credential access, or external command execution. All documented functionality (graph I/O, data processing) is appropriate for the stated purpose of network analysis.

content.value_statement: Working with network data requires specialized tools to model relationships between entities. NetworkX provides a comprehensive Python toolkit for creating, analyzing, and visualizing graphs including shortest paths, centrality measures, community detection, and synthetic network generation.
actual_capabilities: Create and manipulate graph data structures with nodes and edges
Compute graph algorithms including shortest paths, centrality, and clustering
Generate synthetic networks using random and scale-free models
Read and write graphs in multiple formats (GraphML, GML, JSON, CSV)
Visualize networks with customizable layouts and styles
Detect communities and analyze network structure
limitations: Does not include runtime execution environment for NetworkX
Does not provide pre-built datasets beyond standard example graphs
Does not include specialized graph databases or distributed processing

use_cases.title: Social Network Analysis
use_cases.description: Analyze relationships in social networks to identify influential users and community structures.

use_cases.title: Biological Network Modeling
use_cases.description: Model protein interaction networks and gene regulatory networks for biological discovery.

use_cases.title: Route Optimization
use_cases.description: Find shortest paths and optimize routes in transportation and logistics networks.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Graph Creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a graph with nodes representing cities and weighted edges representing distances between them.

prompt_templates.title: Path Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Find the shortest path between node A and node Z in this network graph, accounting for edge weights.

prompt_templates.title: Community Detection
prompt_templates.prompt: Detect communities in this social network graph using greedy modularity optimization.

prompt_templates.title: Network Generation
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a Barabasi-Albert scale-free network with 500 nodes to model preferential attachment behavior.

output_examples.input: Create a graph representing a small social network with 5 people and their friendships
output: Created undirected Graph with 5 nodes and 6 edges
Edge list with weights: Alice-Bob (0.8), Alice-Carb (0.6), Bob-David (0.9), Carol-David (0.7), David-Eve (0.5)

best_practices: Set random seeds (seed=42) for reproducible graph generation and layouts
Use sparse matrices for large graphs to reduce memory usage
Export results to GraphML or pickle format to preserve all attributes
anti_patterns: Using floating-point numbers as edge weights in algorithms requiring exact precision
Loading entire large graphs when only a subgraph is needed
Forgetting to convert between graph types when working with directed data

faq.question: What graph types does NetworkX support?
faq.answer: NetworkX supports Graph (undirected), DiGraph (directed), MultiGraph (multi-edge undirected), and MultiDiGraph (multi-edge directed).

faq.question: How many nodes can NetworkX handle?
faq.answer: NetworkX can handle millions of nodes but performance depends on algorithm complexity and available memory. Use sparse representations for very large networks.

faq.question: Can NetworkX integrate with databases?
faq.answer: Yes, NetworkX can read from and write to SQL databases using pandas DataFrames or through custom connections with libraries like sqlite3.

faq.question: Is data safe when using NetworkX?
faq.answer: Yes, NetworkX is a local processing library. It does not send data over networks. File I/O is controlled by your code and local filesystem.

faq.question: Why are my results approximate?
faq.answer: Results may be approximate when using floating-point weights due to precision limitations. Consider using integer weights for exact computations.

faq.question: How does NetworkX compare to graph databases?
faq.answer: NetworkX is for in-memory graph analysis while databases store persistent graph data. Use NetworkX for computation and databases for large-scale graph storage and querying.
